titleStmt.title: URFA-125
SHAWI Corpus
titleStmt.funder: Funded by the FWF Austrian Science Fund under the number P 33574

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.

spanGrp.span: Once upon a time, my master, there was a coffee boy, who had a place, where coffee is served. In former times, the Arabs used to say in villages, they used to mill coffee, coffee
This man mills coffee, he would consume a kilo of coffee a day, he would consume three hundred and fifty kilos a year, he would eat coffee
that means he consumes coffee, one-two years pass, people come from villages, get entertained and drink, they only drink coffee at the gamgūm and the nafīle (tools for making coffee?)
they keep drinking coffee till the morning, the neighbors at his place, they come from villages, two or three villages on foot, they come to him to drink coffee
they sit at his place, when they sit at his place and drink coffee, a year, two years, three years later this man has become weak, that means, he has got no money left, his money is out
and he is done, he has no power more to take coffee, he can not buy coffee anymore
and he gives up coffee, he has no money, he gathers the gamgūm, the utensils of the coffee and puts them in the corner, he throws them
Someone has recently become rich, close to him, let’s say, close to him by a village or two, someone has recently become replete (rich)
He hears that this old man has left the coffee and says “I will leave from here, I want to go to the old man’s house and I want to make coffee”
He sends for coffee, he makes the gamgūm, he fills them and what not, then he starts to make coffee and pour for people, for his men
he has a man, he sends one of his men to the first old man, to the coffee guy, he says to him “Go and call the old man for us, tell him that ˀIsmāˁīn is inviting you, he is inviting you for coffee”
he says, so he can come, since he has given up his coffee, so he can come and keep drinking coffee at my place, so he would not stay without coffee, he should not stay without coffee!
When he goes and calls him, he says “fine, the old man is asking for you, there you go” and before that man has arrived, the man who is making coffee says to his men

he says “The old man is coming, fill the big gamgūm! The big gamgūm is full and has two cans of coffee in it, which are evaporating, he says to him “Put into it two grains of barley! Put two grains of barley into the coffee and let it boil!”
He says “Alright!” He puts two grains of barley while the coffee is boiling, he does something with it, he makes it bruise, he stirs it, I mean, in the small pot no the big one
When the old man has arrived, the one with the old coffee says “Welcome ˀabu flān (literally father of someone), welcome ˀabu flān!” He starts to welcome him

He says “Please have a seat!” He sits. He says to his man “Pour a cup of coffee for the old man!” He pours a cup of coffee for him. He drinks the coffee, after he has drunk, he wants him to praise his coffee
“How is my coffee, ˀabu flān?” He says “Well, ˀabu flān, your coffee is very good, very good, so good, but if you did not put these two grains of barley into it, it would have been even better”
This man stands and says “Wow! I have put the two grains of barley into the two cans of coffee, and this man knows that I have put two grains of barley into it!
That means, this man makes a good coffee.” that means, a tasty coffee, we say k¬¬ēfči. He says “Fine” After he has drunk the coffee he says “Brother, you are”
He asks him saying “How much coffee do you drink a year?” He says “Brother, I drink three hundred and fifty kilos of coffee a year” He says “O ˀabu flān, you are not able and do not have any
get up (to his men) and pick the utensils of the coffee and take it! Your three hundred and fifty kilos of coffee a year are on me until you die. The coffee will be done at your place again
You are, brother, I mean, a real taster of coffee, and you... I am not a coffee guy, you are the coffee guy.
He picks all the utensils, cleans them up and takes them to the old man, he even takes his utensils. and he buys for him three hundred and fifty kilos of coffee
and says “We will keep coming to drink coffee at your place. You are a coffee guy. The coffee is again at your place

You are a real coffee taster. The coffee is not my business” The Arabs say “If it is not what you are good at (literally, if it is not your job/profession/ business), it will destroy your home” It is your thing, brother, It is not mine. The coffee is your thing, therefore, the coffee will be made at your place”
